page.title: 05Buildings in Ampleforth.
page.content: The majority of older houses are stone built: brick was frowned on by local builders. The walls are either rubble with lime mortar infill of coursed stone. Windows are of three types: Sash, Casement and Yorkshire (sliding horizontally). Roofs are tiled with clay or slate; no thatched houses remain, but one{Cruck House}still does. The clay came originally from a brick works in the village. The slates come from Westmoreland or Wales. Apart from domestic buildings there is an Anglican church, a Catholic church and two Methodist Chapels (one in use). There are now only four food shops, a petrol station, two public houses and several craft workshops. Unusual for the area there are two primary schools and two village halls.
